introduction.p: Each problem below defines two finite sets, X and Y. Create a bijective proof to show that |X|=|Y|. You must define a bijection f : X \rightarrow Y between the two sets, and then either (1) show f is both injective and surjective, or (2) define a function g: Y \rightarrow X and show that f and g are inverse functions.

statement.p:
For a given positive integer n
Let X = \{ 0 , 1 \}^n be the collection of binary sequences of length n.
Let Y = {\mathcal{P}}([n]) be the power set of [n], which is the set of all subsets of [n].

For given positive integers 0 \leq k \leq n,
Let X be the collection of k-subsets of [n], and
Let Y be the collection of (n-k)-subsets.
(The k-subsets of [n] are all the subsets of size k).
For any positive integer n, we can partition the power set \cP([n]) into two sets: the set \cE_n of even-sized subsets and the set \cO_n of odd-sized subsets.

In this problem, you will show that | \cE_n | = | \cO_n | via a bijective proof. Since | \cP([n]) = 2^n, this means that | \cE_n | = | \cO_n | = 2^{n-1}.
We start with a proof that only works when n=2k+1 is odd.
List all the subsets of [3].
Pair each set with its complement. What do you notice?
Now give a bijective proof that when n is odd, | \cE_n | = | \cO_n | .
Now we consider the case where n is even.
List all the subsets of [4].
Pair each set with its complement. Why doesn't this lead to a proof of the result?
We now give a bijective proof that works for both even and odd n. Consider the following mapping f : \cE_n \rightarrow \cO_n. For S \in \cP([n]), we define
f(S) = \left\{ \begin{array}{cl} S \backslash \{ 1 \} & \mbox{if } 1 \in S, \\ S \cup \{ 1 \} & \mbox{if } 1 \notin S. \end{array} \right.
Explain why f: \cE_n \rightarrow \cO_n is well defined, meaning that an even set is always mapped to an odd set.
Now prove that f is a bijection.
